document.docTitle: Hemilobella ferrumequinum study & paper & time & Caledonia & Panié & Deharveng & Deharveng & Paris 2008, n. sp.
document.masterDocTitle: First record of the tribe Lobellini (Collembola: Neanuridae: Neanurinae) in New Caledonia: a new species of the genus Hemilobella Deharveng & Greenslade, 1992 from Mont Panié

subSubSection.paragraph: ETYMOLOGY. — Named after the presence of a peculiar sclerified horseshoe-like structure in the labrum.

DESCRIPTION. —
Length: 2.5 to 4 mm ( holotype female 3.6 mm on slide). Color: white in alcohol, red alive. Habitus large and flat (Fig. 1). No cryptopygy. Abd. VI fused with Abd. V dorsally, feebly bilobed. Tubercles weakly or not developed dorsally, indicated by an arrangement of secondary granules different from surrounding tegument. No reticulations or tertiary granules. Dorsal ordinary chaetae of four types differing in length, but similar in morphology: long macrochaetae, short macrochaetae, mesochaetae and microchaetae. Long macrochaetae (Ml) long, thin, smooth or minutely scaled at high magnification, not sheathed, pointed or finely blunt apically. Short macrochaetae (Mc) distincly shorter, smooth (about 2/3 to 1/3 the length of the closest Ml). Mesochaetae and microchaetae thin and acuminate. S chaetae of tergites thin and long, as long as closest macrochaetae
.

Mouthparts reduced, mandible with three strong teeth, the apical one subdivided in 3 or 4 toothlets. Maxilla styliform, made of two appressed lamellae devoid of apical denticles. Labrum elongated, apically rounded, with a conspicuous small horseshoe-like thickening at 2/3 of its length (Fig. 2). Labium elongated, with four basal (E, F, G, f), 3 distal (A, C, D) and 3 lateral chaetae (c, d, e). Eyes unpigmented, 3 + 3. Antennae shorter than head. Sgd of Ant. III

FIG. 1-8. 1 , habitus. 2 , distal part of the labrum, with the horseshoe structure. 3 , apex of Ant. IV with its multilobed vesical bulb. 4 , dorsal chaetotaxy of the right part of the head, with chaetae names of the Fr and An chaetal groups, and the names of the posterior and lateral chaetal groups. 5 , tergite chaetotaxy of Abd. II-VI. 6 , buttonhole of the left tergite of Abd. IV. 7 , furcal rest on Abd. III sternite (upper = anterior). 8 , claw of leg III.
not shift up to Ant. IV. A supernumerary chaeta m present dorsally on Ant. IV. Apical bulb of Ant. 4 IV subdivided in multiple lobes similar to elongated secondary granules (Fig. 3).
Head dorsal chaetotaxy (Table 1; Fig. 4). Di2 ahead of Di1 and De2 ahead of De1. The Dl group of chaetae is without tubercle.

Tergite chaetotaxy (Table 1; Fig. 5). On Th. II-III, the chaeta Di1 is much closer to Di2 than to Di3. On Abd. IV, De and Dl are grouped but separated by a well marked longitudinal buttonhole (Fig. 6), and located posteriorly to Di and L tubercles, almost at the level of Di of Abd. V. A transversal and less marked buttonhole is present behind Dl of Abd. IV.

Furcal rest prominent, without microchaetae (Fig. 7). Chaeta M on tibiotarsus is a small microchaeta. Claw granulated basally, striated internally and with a tooth at 1/3-1/4 of its inner crest (Fig. 8). Male sternites without modified chaetae.

DISCUSSION. —
Hemilobella ferrumequinum
exhibits two characters unique among Lobellini : (i) the small, sclerotised horseshoe structure present on the ventral side of the labrum, probably imbeded in its ventral cuticle; this conspicuous structure was not seen in
H. pluvia
nor in
H. rounsevelli
, nor in any other Lobellini or Neanurinae that we examined so far; (ii) its apical bulb of Ant. IV is multilobed, which has only been described in some Japanese
Coecoloba Yosii 1956
among Neanurinae . The new species is ascribed to the genus
Hemilobella Deharveng & Greenslade 1992
after the presence of two chaetae on each cephalic tubercles Di and De. Like some species of the genus (
H. rounsevelli
and
H. newmani
), it has additional S chaetae on L tubercle of Abd. I-II. It has also an additional chaeta m on Ant IV, like
Lobella sokamensis Deharveng & Weiner, 1984
from Korea . It is not possible to state which
Hemilobella species
is closest to
H. ferrumequinum
, but the different species of the genus can be separated according to the key below.

Hemilobella ferrumequinum
n. sp. is frequent in the litter at all altitudes of the Mont Panié, and especially abundant near the summit. We did not find the species elsewhere in the island, where other undescribed Lobellini are frequent.

KEY TO
HEMILOBELLA SPECIES

paragraph.keyLead:
4. 2 chaetae Di on Abd. I-III; 4 + S chaetae De on Th. II .........
ferrumequinum
n.sp. ( New Caledonia )

subSubSection.paragraph:
Lobella daeana Lee, 1982
described from South Korea is transferred here to
Hemilobella
. It has the characteristic cephalic pattern of this genus, i.e. 2 chaetae on each tubercles Di and De.
Hemilobella daeana
is very similar to
H. perakensis
in chaetal arrangement, and both species have thick, distally enlarged and apically rounded macrochaetae.

ACKNOWLEDGMENTS The material was collected during a trip supported by the programme pluriformation of the Muséum national d’Histoire naturelle of Paris “Biodiversité terrestre en Nouvelle-Calédonie ”, coordinated by Judith Najt.
